<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 293, 210, 305]]<|/det|> **MATHEMATICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 293, 866, 305]]<|/det|> 9709/61 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 313, 371, 327]]<|/det|> Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 1 (S1) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[677, 313, 866, 327]]<|/det|> October/November 2019 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[725, 335, 866, 347]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 354, 395, 367]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 375, 438, 388]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 373, 413]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 428, 747, 442]]<|/det|> Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 443, 314, 456]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 457, 485, 471]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 472, 485, 485]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 486, 368, 499]]<|/det|> **DO NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 514, 866, 541]]<|/det|> Answer **all** the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 542, 866, 570]]<|/det|> Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 571, 566, 584]]<|/det|> The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 579, 598]]<|/det|> You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 613, 579, 626]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 628, 720, 641]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 643, 420, 656]]<|/det|> The total number of marks for this paper is 50. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 828, 703, 841]]<|/det|> This document consists of 14 printed pages and 2 blank pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 72, 87, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 134]]<|/det|>
When Shona goes to college she either catches the bus with probability 0.8 or she cycles with probability 0.2. If she catches the bus, the probability that she is late is 0.4. If she cycles, the probability that she is late is \(x\). The probability that Shona is not late for college on a randomly chosen day is 0.63. Find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 103]]<|/det|>
Annan has designed a new logo for a sportswear company. A survey of a large number of customers found that \(42\%\) of customers rated the logo as good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 114, 149, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 114, 875, 147]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 10 customers is chosen. Find the probability that fewer than 8 of them rate the logo as good.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 515, 875, 562]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 89, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 70, 875, 102]]<|/det|> In a probability distribution the random variable \(X\) takes the values \(-1\), \(0\), \(1\), \(2\), \(4\). The probability distribution table for \(X\) is as follows. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 106, 702, 158]]<|/det|>
\(x\)\(-1\)\(0\)\(1\)\(2\)\(4\)
\(\mathrm {P}(X=x)\)\(\frac {1}{4}\)\(p\)\(p\)\(\frac {3}{8}\)\(4p\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 171, 148, 189]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 171, 301, 189]]<|/det|> Find the value of \(p\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 171, 876, 189]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 495, 178, 514]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 495, 326, 514]]<|/det|> Find \(\mathrm {E}(X)\) and \(\mathrm {Var}(X)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 496, 876, 514]]<|/det|> [3]

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 70, 875, 103]]<|/det|>
Ransha measured the lengths, in centimetres, of 160 palm leaves. His results are illustrated in the cumulative frequency graph below.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 125, 823, 484]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 505, 148, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 702, 523]]<|/det|>
Estimate how many leaves have a length between 14 and 24 centimetres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 505, 876, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 702, 141, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 774, 720]]<|/det|>
10% of the leaves have a length of \(L\) centimetres or more. Estimate the value of \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 702, 876, 720]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 71, 623, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 71, 876, 87]]<|/det|>
